So said  Curt Sampson  on  2/7/2003 --------------------

>On Thu, 6 Feb 2003, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>> Pushing every SQL statement you use out to a ResourceBundle (or
other
>> metadata file) is a good idea.
>
>Eww! I know this tends to be a bit of a personal preference, but I far
>prefer to keep my code together when I can. If a statement is used in
>only one place, keeping it where it's used makes the code much easier
to
>read, because you don't have to go chasing off into some other file to
>find out what SQL statement is being executed.
>
>> It's very easy to write a single test
>> that runs through all the SQL statements in the metadata file and do
a
>> sanity check on them: can I read the columns from the tables I
SELECT?
>> and so on.
>
>Well, for the simple stuff, why bother? If I have a method like:
>
>    public void setCount(int count) {
>	if (count == _count)
>	    return;
>	DB.update("UPDATE mytable SET count = ? WHERE id = ?",
>	    new Object() { new Integer(_id), new Integer(_count), });
>	_count = count;
>    }
>
>Doesn't it seem like a lot more work to move that statement out to a
>separate file than just to test the whole method with a single test?

More work, yes, but with serious ROI. 

If I test your implementation rather than just checking the SQL string,
then I have to run that  at a cost of say, 1 second per run. Now let
there be 150 such statements -- not unusual for an application of any
decent size -- and the difference is at least 2-1/2 minutes per test
run OR I simply don't run those tests. (If I knew ahead of time what
would break, then I wouldn't want to run all the tests all the time,
but I don't, so I do.) Now I run my tests at least three times per
hour, so that's 7-1/2 minutes per hour or about 10% overhead. Assuming
a linear average over the lifetime of the project, then the we really
have 5% overhead. On a six-month project with six developers pairing,
that means upwards of 120 days x 7.5 hours per day x 3 pairs x 5% = 135
hours of overhead just to run the tests. That's 18 days spent just to
run those tests. Nevermind the context switching that comes from
chatting while the tests run or skipping over to my web browser to
avoid staring at the test run for 3 minutes.

Do you think that the time needed to push all that SQL out to a
properties file PLUS the time needed to consult that properties file
PLUS the time spent arguing about whether to do it is as much as HALF
of that over the length of a six-month, six-person project?

Remember: it's not just about execution time, and it's not just about
development time. Gotta compute 'em both.
